quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A lot of early stage founders get tripped up as they're taking late stage sales advice. The founder is the product. You have studied. You have experienced something that most of the market hasn't even had a chance to maybe see or visualize yet.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Reframes founder-led sales as fundamentally different from late-stage sales, positioning the founder’s unique insight as the core asset.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So if you can focus the messaging in a way that speaks to something that is a bit of shock value or is counterintuitive, you'll get them to continue reading. When a problem is truly being felt by the market, people will get on a call, people will respond.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Gives a concrete outreach tactic: use counterintuitive or surprising framing tied to a real pain to drive replies and calls.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You need to be vulnerable. I would be very open and honest with where you are. Hey, I'm an early stage startup. We have a lot to learn. Can we kind of gain your insight into how this problem is manifesting on your side? Founder led sales is not about revenue on day one. It is about learning as fast as humanly possible to get to that pulse, so that you can earn the right to sell.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a practical call script and a mental model: early founder-led sales prioritizes rapid learning to earn credibility before pushing for revenue.

quotes.topic_title: What founder-led sales means and why it matters
quotes.text: Founder led sales is really that first milestone that a startup goes through on the commercial side, which is, how do I go out and get my first few customers?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Defines founder-led sales as an explicit early commercial milestone, framing it as a concrete objective founders must personally drive.

quotes.topic_title: What founder-led sales means and why it matters
quotes.text: Some people might say zero to one, which is, how do I get my first million? Others might say, how do I go out and get my first 10 customers? It's all kind of in the same vein.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Offers practical yardsticks for what “zero-to-one” means commercially, giving founders measurable targets to orient early sales efforts.

quotes.topic_title: What founder-led sales means and why it matters
quotes.text: And founder led sales is really, really, really important because in the very, very, very early days, when there is no brand equity, when there is no marketing engine running, when there is limited to no reference ability, the founder is the product, right?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why founders must sell early: credibility and conviction substitute for missing brand, marketing, and references.

quotes.topic_title: What founder-led sales means and why it matters
quotes.text: You have studied, you have experienced something that most of the market hasn't even had a chance to maybe see or visualize yet.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Explains the founder’s unique advantage in early sales—selling from firsthand, ahead-of-the-market insight rather than product features.

quotes.topic_title: What founder-led sales means and why it matters
quotes.text: So founder led sales is how do you bring the founders vision into the world and have the market, and understand what part of the market accepts it, and then what part of that vision are they accepting? So it's aligning the founders vision with the market reality.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a clear methodology: use early sales to test which segments accept the vision and which parts resonate, then align accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And this is counter to what many founders hope is, I'm just going to hire a salesperson, they'll handle sales. I'll build the thing, I'll wait for them to find deals.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Challenges the common founder assumption that sales can be delegated early without founder involvement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And founder led sales is the movement of just like, no, no, you should be doing the sales for a long time as a founder.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear prescription that founders should personally own sales longer than they expect.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights how quickly security/compliance complexity escalates, motivating early process/tooling decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC II, ISO 27,001, HIPAA and more, with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable approach: consolidate risk, trust, and compliance workflows into one system to reduce overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Why founders shouldn’t delegate early sales
quotes.text: I don't think people realize how much of a competitive advantage the founder led sales motion is, for three specific reasons.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Frames founder-led sales as a durable competitive advantage and introduces a clear 3-part rationale practitioners can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Why founders shouldn’t delegate early sales
quotes.text: And then that third piece is that the founder can see something budding in a conversation that a salesperson won't be able to see. And it's those budding moments that's where all the gold lives.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model (“budding moments”) for why founders should stay close to early customer conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Why founders shouldn’t delegate early sales
quotes.text: Their day one market vision is never the same vision that takes them in a product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that early sales calls are a discovery loop that reshapes positioning and product toward PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Why founders shouldn’t delegate early sales
quotes.text: They had 10 to 15 conversations a day for weeks, and then they're like realizing people keep telling us they like it, but no one's buying, no one's excited enough to want to actually move forward. And that was only happening because the founders were on these calls.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example (with a specific cadence) showing how founder-led calls surface the gap between polite interest and real demand.

quotes.topic_title: Why founders shouldn’t delegate early sales
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean, the other thing too is that it becomes a game of telephone. It's like, hey, this salesperson says that no cares about this. What do you think the first thing the founder's going to say is? It's the salesperson. So much easier to say that than, is it me? Is it my vision? So it also kind of brings the accountability closer to the pulse where decisions are made.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Warns against delegating early sales because it distorts feedback and weakens accountability for fixing messaging and vision.

quotes.topic_title: Sales cycle stages and how buyers influence them
quotes.text: The traditional sales stages that most CRMs are even set up as is you have your intro call. You have your second call, which sometimes could be the demo depending on the stage of market you're selling to. Then you have your third call, which is going to be more about walking through a proposal, a scope of work, maybe going deeper into the demo to contextualize it to everything you've learned. The fourth call is going to be getting their feedback and kind of co-authoring that scope of work even further. The fifth call is going to be around probably an introduction to procurement. And then selling into procurement in itself, it's its own little sales cycle, but we could talk about that in a sec. And then post-procurement, it's going to be obviously getting that signature and knowing who the actual signatory is. Sometimes it's not even the business unit, it's sometimes legal, CFO, procurement themselves. So just understanding who that is.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A concrete, end-to-end sales-cycle framework founders can map directly to CRM stages and call goals (including procurement and signatory identification).

quotes.topic_title: Sales cycle stages and how buyers influence them
quotes.text: it's also predicated on their buying process as well. So if they're really used to buying, if they're very mature in their buying process, they actually might guide you to what the steps are.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Highlights that the buyer’s maturity can dictate your sales process, so sellers should adapt rather than force a rigid sequence.

quotes.topic_title: Sales cycle stages and how buyers influence them
quotes.text: But most startups are turning non-consumers into consumers. So that's why this kind of fits well.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A mental model for why startups often need to define the buying journey themselves—because they’re creating new buying behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Sales cycle stages and how buyers influence them
quotes.text: The challenge is, okay, so great, founders should be doing sales. Most founders have never done sales. They just want to build product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the core founder-led sales problem: founders must sell despite lacking sales experience and preferring product work.

quotes.topic_title: Outbound messaging that earns the first meeting
quotes.text: So first and foremost, I usually like to open it with, which is why is this relevant for me in my role?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical opener that prioritizes role-based relevance as the hook for outbound messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Outbound messaging that earns the first meeting
quotes.text: So first and foremost is relevancy. I think that matters even more so than personalization right now.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian take that challenges the common “personalize everything” outbound playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Outbound messaging that earns the first meeting
quotes.text: So say something that would literally make them say what?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for using counterintuitive insight to earn attention and keep readers engaged.

quotes.topic_title: Outbound messaging that earns the first meeting
quotes.text: And the most important piece is getting this done where, if they get it on their mobile phone, which everyone is looking at their mobile phone and on email, they don't have to scroll. So usually three to four sentences max.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A concrete constraint (no scrolling; 3–4 sentences) that makes outbound messages more readable and effective.

quotes.topic_title: Outbound messaging that earns the first meeting
quotes.text: Actually our first three years were built on cold email before we actually had clients, before we got word of mouth from the founders we worked with, I cold emailed the first 20 customers we had at Jellyfish. And the line I used in there was zero to one sales talent doesn't exist.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A specific early-stage example showing how a provocative thesis line can drive initial customer conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion rates, win rates, and PMF signals
quotes.text: So if you have a really high win rate, let's say 30 or 40%, you actually don't need as high of a conversion rate on the outbound, because you know if you get someone in the funnel, the throughput is very healthy. If your win rate is really low, you need that conversion rate to be much, much higher, because you need more and more and more at bats.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical way to size outbound effort by reverse-engineering from win rate rather than obsessing over top-of-funnel reply rates.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion rates, win rates, and PMF signals
quotes.text: I would say a healthy conversion rate from outbound probably sits around, when it's mature, around five to 7%. Sometimes it could be two to 3%. Sometimes I've seen eight to 15% because it's coming from the founder, and they're solving a really heartfelt problem.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides concrete benchmark ranges and highlights when founder-led outreach can materially outperform typical outbound.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion rates, win rates, and PMF signals
quotes.text: And everyone wants to keep going back to, well, email rate is really low, email doesn't work anymore. LinkedIn, I'm not getting the connects I want. Yes, you can argue that the game has changed a little bit, but when a problem is truly being felt by the market, people will get on a call. People will respond.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterpoints the common “channels are dead” narrative by tying response rates to problem intensity rather than tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Conversion rates, win rates, and PMF signals
quotes.text: And we're doing nothing different. The only thing that's different is the insight that the founder has on the market, which is a hard pill to swallow. And I know that's hard to hear too.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A memorable diagnostic: if tactics are constant but interest varies widely, the differentiator is the founder’s market insight (a PMF signal).

quotes.topic_title: Conversion rates, win rates, and PMF signals
quotes.text: But the vast majority of the time, maybe you're just not saying anything interesting at all. Maybe the problem you're looking to solve just isn't widely felt. Maybe the perspective you have needs another level of refinement because you're just not getting those bites.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for founders to treat low response as a messaging/problem-definition issue before blaming outbound mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Market-first vs product-first paths to PMF
quotes.text: There's this thing in my head and I haven't fully validated it but I'm going to share it with you, which is did they start with the market problem first and then build the product? Because they knew who their market was right off the bat. Versus an air table and a figma that I think started with a technical insight and then were trying to find their market.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Introduces a useful lens for diagnosing PMF timelines: market-first (known buyer/problem) vs technical-insight-first (find market later).

quotes.topic_title: Market-first vs product-first paths to PMF
quotes.text: Vanta, the way they approached it, Christina, she was searching for a pain. She was obsessed with talking to everybody about a pain that they needed solved, and then she just built it in spreadsheets. So she started with the market very much so.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of a market-first approach: intensive pain discovery before building, with a lightweight spreadsheet prototype.

quotes.topic_title: Market-first vs product-first paths to PMF
quotes.text: And I think product market fit when you start with the market first, it's accelerated. But I will say this, I think that it's also capped on the upside.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive tradeoff: faster PMF via market-first discovery may come with a ceiling on long-term upside.

quotes.topic_title: Market-first vs product-first paths to PMF
quotes.text: Starting with a product is a hell of a lot riskier.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Blunt risk framing that helps founders choose between product-first experimentation and market-first validation.

quotes.topic_title: Market-first vs product-first paths to PMF
quotes.text: And this is where I come back to so many people will say, how did you get funding and not know who your market is? And it's like, because if they do find it, that's a really, really, really big win.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Explains why investors sometimes back product-first teams pre-market: the payoff can be enormous if they later discover the right market.

quotes.topic_title: Finding leads: start manual before tools
quotes.text: So I say before you buy any tool, don't even think about tools.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian starting point: delay tooling and focus on fundamentals before scaling outbound.

quotes.topic_title: Finding leads: start manual before tools
quotes.text: So I think before you even overthink about the tools right now, can you manually find 30 people that you want to spend 15 to 20 minutes writing a rock solid note to?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable exercise for validating ICP and outreach quality before automation.

quotes.topic_title: Finding leads: start manual before tools
quotes.text: Okay, so now you're starting to collect some parameters. Just by doing this exercise, you're starting to collect some parameters around who you want to learn from and sell to.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Turns manual prospecting into an ICP-discovery method by extracting shared attributes from a small set.

quotes.topic_title: Finding leads: start manual before tools
quotes.text: If it's zero, it begs the question, do you now want to do another 30 in a very similar fashion? Do you want to change the messaging a little bit? Now it forces these natural experiments.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A simple iteration loop: use response rates to drive controlled experiments on targeting and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Finding leads: start manual before tools
quotes.text: Parameters then allow you to do really strong enrichment with a clay. You now know the types of questions to give it. If you're not asking it the right questions, these enrichment tools, these sales tools will yield nothing.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical mental model for when tools start working: only after you’ve defined the right parameters and questions.

quotes.topic_title: Outreach recap: structure, tone, and “better” trap
quotes.text: One of a great little tactical test is on Gmail, you can highlight the message and then have it replay it back to you from an audio perspective.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical QA tactic for outreach emails to catch tone issues and improve clarity before sending.

quotes.topic_title: Outreach recap: structure, tone, and “better” trap
quotes.text: You'd be shocked how many notes I've changed when it replays it back and I'm like, oh, that sounds really passive-aggressive.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Highlights how reading/listening to your own copy can reveal unintended tone that hurts response rates.

quotes.topic_title: Outreach recap: structure, tone, and “better” trap
quotes.text: You don't even need to talk about the solution. That's the big takeaway, which is if you get any sales email, you get what's the primary focus of that email? It's usually like here's what we do. But I bet if someone reached out to you with a novel insight and said, I'm really passionate about solving this problem, if it's something you're focused on, you'd probably reply.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A counterintuitive outreach framework: lead with problem + insight rather than pitching the product.

quotes.topic_title: Outreach recap: structure, tone, and “better” trap
quotes.text: One of the worst things someone can say to me is we're better than X product. Then I ask them to define that. And then I ask them, okay, how do we measure that? And then I say, okay, should we give this company another year to give them this feedback before we make this huge transition and disrupt momentum?" Yeah, better is a dangerous place.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A procurement leader’s reasoning explains why “better than X” claims trigger scrutiny and stall deals.

quotes.topic_title: Outreach recap: structure, tone, and “better” trap
quotes.text: I invest in a bunch of startups and I find it's impossible to get anyone to care if things are good enough with what they got today. I'm happy not using the best possible product if my life is okay. And I have so many other things I got to do, I'll just deal with this good enough solution for now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A reminder that “good enough” inertia is the real competitor, so outreach must surface a painful problem worth switching for.

quotes.topic_title: First call: vulnerability to unlock honest feedback
quotes.text: One is you need to be vulnerable. You're an early stage startup, okay.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Sets the core tactic for first calls: lead with vulnerability to create a more honest, productive conversation.

quotes.topic_title: First call: vulnerability to unlock honest feedback
quotes.text: So when you speak to them, I would be very open and honest with where you are. Hey, I'm an early stage startup. We are deeply passionate about solving this specific problem. We have a lot to learn. Here's how we are thinking about it from a problem priority perspective. Can we gain your insight into how this problem is manifesting on your side?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a practical talk track founders can use to frame the call as learning and elicit detailed customer insight.

quotes.topic_title: First call: vulnerability to unlock honest feedback
quotes.text: If you tell them you have a fully baked, ready to go product, they're not going to give you honest feedback.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive risk of sounding too polished: it reduces the quality and candor of feedback.

quotes.topic_title: First call: vulnerability to unlock honest feedback
quotes.text: But when you're vulnerable and when you tell them it's not fully built yet, even if it is, you will get more raw and honest feedback.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism for unlocking candid feedback: positioning the product as unfinished makes it easier for buyers to critique.

quotes.topic_title: First call: vulnerability to unlock honest feedback
quotes.text: So the further you suggest you are, you're actually going to hamstring a lot of the intel, hamstring yourself on gaining a lot of the intel. So that's one counterintuitive thing that I think a lot of founders don't realize.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Summarizes the mental model: overstating maturity actively reduces learning, which is the main goal of early founder-led sales calls.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But building these integrations in-house cost an average of three months of engineering according to the 2024 state of integration survey, which results in difficult roadmap trade-offs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Quantifies the typical engineering cost of building integrations and highlights the opportunity cost on product roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This is why engineering teams at Copy AI, AI21, and over 100 other B2B SaaS companies use Paragon, so they can focus their efforts on core product features, not integrations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a prioritization heuristic: outsource integrations to keep engineering focused on differentiated core features.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The results, they've shipped integrations seven times faster, all while avoiding the never-ending maintenance that comes with rolling your own integrations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete performance claim and a reminder that maintenance burden is a major hidden cost of DIY integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Early vs late-stage sales and learning vs revenue
quotes.text: founder led sales is not about revenue on day one. It is about learning as fast as humanly possible to get to that pulse, so that you can earn the right to sell.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Reframes founder-led sales as a learning engine first, not a revenue function, guiding how founders should prioritize early conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Early vs late-stage sales and learning vs revenue
quotes.text: There's this concept that I talk about, which is you're going out to run sales to collect the research, which is what founder led sales is. And then you have sales for revenue, which is that post founder led sales stage.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Provides a two-phase model—sales-as-research vs sales-for-revenue—to clarify what “good” looks like at different stages.

quotes.topic_title: Early vs late-stage sales and learning vs revenue
quotes.text: I think it's about, some people say 500, some people say a million. I think if you get to 500K really, really fast, then I think absolutely you can move out of it. If you get to 500K really, really, really slow, you might not want to get out of it right away. You haven't reached that velocity point yet.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Gives a practical milestone (and a nuance about growth velocity) for when to transition away from founder-led sales.

quotes.topic_title: Early vs late-stage sales and learning vs revenue
quotes.text: I have this theory that maybe you shouldn't hire any salespeople until series A, right? Because seed is all about experimentation and proving out that experiment, and then obviously series A is about exploiting that learning.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A contrarian hiring heuristic that ties sales hiring to stage-specific goals: experimentation at seed, scaling at Series A.

quotes.topic_title: Early vs late-stage sales and learning vs revenue
quotes.text: their first founder led sales motion was they just reached out on LinkedIn to heads of procurement, and just leaned into what you're saving more, which is we just want your advice on this product that we're building. Just tell us what problems you have. It was very advice oriented versus we want to sell you this thing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of an advice-first outreach script founders can copy to maximize learning and reduce buyer resistance.

quotes.topic_title: Discovery questions and signs of real pull
quotes.text: But more importantly, where's that aha moment unlocked for them? Because when they start getting their gears churning in their head about, and this is the beauty about not having a product and not showing them anything, they're visualizing in their head now.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive discovery tactic: avoid demos early so prospects build their own mental model and reveal what they truly want.

quotes.topic_title: Discovery questions and signs of real pull
quotes.text: Great understanding. Is it being measured? Is it being managed and have they tried to solve for it? The leading indicators that you're onto something here.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical PMF signal checklist you can use in discovery to validate real pain vs. casual interest.

quotes.topic_title: Discovery questions and signs of real pull
quotes.text: So I think the first is it has to be a growing and widening problem. No one's going to spend time fixing a pretty fixed problem, because it's not necessarily really a priority anymore.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A prioritization gate: only pursue problems that are expanding, because static pains rarely command budget or urgency.

quotes.topic_title: Discovery questions and signs of real pull
quotes.text: And what you're psychologically doing is now you're flipping them into a buyer where they're like, wait a second, hold on. I need to bring on so-and-so on the next call, they also think that this is not good enough.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A behavioral buying signal: when discovery is working, prospects start recruiting stakeholders unprompted.

quotes.topic_title: Discovery questions and signs of real pull
quotes.text: Absolutely. And that's when you know there's some momentum behind it, which is when they're bringing in other colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A simple “pull” metric for founder-led sales: momentum shows up as internal championing and multi-threading.

quotes.topic_title: Closing the call and co-authoring scope via services
quotes.text: Get the second call booked on the first call.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage closing tactic that increases momentum and reduces drop-off after the first call.

quotes.topic_title: Closing the call and co-authoring scope via services
quotes.text: Pull up calendars. Look at calendars. Who else should be invited? It's just a natural evolution to ending the call.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A concrete method for turning the end of a call into a collaborative next step rather than a vague follow-up.

quotes.topic_title: Closing the call and co-authoring scope via services
quotes.text: Maybe they're just being honest and they don't have their calendar available, but nine times out of 10, it's usually I don't have the heart to tell you I'm not interested.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A practical read on buyer behavior that helps founders interpret “I’ll email you” as a leading indicator of low intent.

quotes.topic_title: Closing the call and co-authoring scope via services
quotes.text: If they do not have an existing process or strategy to solve X problem, they can't buy a technology yet, which means you need to sell them. And this is why I go back to you need to sell them some form of a service, right?
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A diagnostic framework for matching the offer to buyer maturity: services first when the customer lacks process/strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Closing the call and co-authoring scope via services
quotes.text: You absolutely need to time box this. I would time box it as 90 days and then what you can say in the next 90 days, we'll scope where we are and what you need.
quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.context: A specific, repeatable way to contain services engagements while preserving flexibility and creating a path to product adoption.
